comments.commentBody: Would not care if Bin Laden was asleep. If I recall correctly, he was wanted dead or alive. The dissection of what really happened during this raid is pointless. The goal was to catch this massive murderer and that was indeed the end result.
I doubt that he was to be taken alive, a quick end to a long story.

Osama bin Laden alive would have been an acute embarrasment to the United States.The decision to double tap him is totally acceptable in the circumstances.This was a high profile raid which had to be one with the right ending,, which it was,

As several comments mention: he's dead. Gone. Finished. Kaput. The details ultimately don't matter.

But reports of increased security at major points in the USA have me worried, and the thought came to me: if someone killed the Pope, would the Catholic Church cease to exist? I fear that Bush's "War on Terror" is far from over.
So American forces murdered an unarmed man, after which Americans crowded into the streets to celebrate.  Makes me proud to be an American!

Without being in the room with night vision goggles, none of us can judge whether OBL should have been taken dead or alive.  It is very sad that our nation had to endure a 10 year manhunt for this terrorist but perhaps even sadder that we cannot trust that our government did the right thing in the end.  From what I know, I think the Seals were incredibly brave and I am thankful that we have people like them devoted to serving our country.
Unarmed when he died?  So were all those innocent people in the planes and buildings on 9/11 who died in the most terrifying painful manner.
He was armed, insofar as he was surrounded by others who were and who would fire at his command.

Open Letter and comment to Barack Obama and his staff:  Good, mission accomplished.  Now bring the troops home from that horrid, wretched, violent and primitive and tribal part of the world and put Americans back to work vs. striking poses for CNN and the NY Times and "Feed your own people" who have lost their homes, jobs, dignity and futures.

Okay, so the situation is that these SEALs were in involved in an intense gun battle on two floors below where bin Laden was. They burst into the room on the third floor and it's dark. There's commotion. What would your reaction be? Right, shoot first. I'm willing to bet that they did not know it was bin Laden when they shot him. It should be pointed out that this was not a police action, but was a military action. There is a big difference.

Even with all that said. I do not believe that someone who masterminded the death of 3000 people--let alone the fact they were US citizens--and more importantly admitted it going as far as taking pride in the act deserves to live. I'm an ardent critic of the death penalty mainly because the legal system can and does get it wrong. But someone like bin Laden does not deserve to live.

It sickens me that the Neo-cons are implying that harsh interrogation techniques (aka torture) played a big role in the gathering of evidence that eventually led to the death of this terrorist. Torture techniques lead to those tortured making things up in the fervent hope that those torturing them will stop. Period. If relevant evidence was obtained from detainees at GITMO it was not produced using torture. That pols are actually saying the opposite shows how very little the USA resembles the so-called shining city on the hill.

The illegal, immoral, unamerican, torture techniques should only result in one thing: trials for Bush Jr., chicken-hawk Cheney, and the authors of the ridiculous memos that allowed these un-american activities to occur.

Every detail I've heard including this one about UBL being unarmed still points to the greatest special operation in modern history.  For most of the naysayers, just be glad that this country produces such men who would place themselves between you and the likes of Bin Laden.  War is regrettable but it has NEVER been done more professionally than the warriors who carried out this mission - planners to pilots to SEALS and their JSOC and CIA buddies.  Great work and it is my honor to serve in the same military with you!
Releasing a photograph of Bin Laden dead would be in such very poor taste. In additon, many people can so very easily alter a photograph these days what real proof of his death would it be?
Whats done is done. Who cares about the dignity of a man who carried out his life like a vicious animal?  I am a New Yorker and I understand that those who differ in opinion are not.
Who cares?  He was public enemy #1, an enemy combatant during a war, and he was responsible for the deaths of 3000 Americans.  The press is reaching for a story.

I've read at The Guardian Newspaper that Bush's aides are claiming that Bin Laden's Death Justifies torture, also picking up on that sentiment in some comments posted here. Has anyone considered that the US may have gotten Bin Laden SOONER by using methods other than torture. And Bush's have NOTHING to crow about. Their fake war in Iraq undoubtedly directed lives, resources, time away from the effective, precise, patient operation President Obama signed off on.

Will I be allowed to enjoy the road to 3,000 or is this it? Jeter deserves better than the constant barrage of negativity. Let him find it...in the meantime, I hope that beat writers and fans realize that we all have a better story if he succeeds. Don't turn against him. It's ugly.

I haven't set this It's important to pursue the science that might clarify a connection, and it's important to get busy finding ways to curb global growth in greenhouse gases. But neither of those activities are relevant to policy questions related to cutting vulnerability to terrible tornadoes in the American South, to my mind.

You may have missed this line:

Finding ways to curb emissions of greenhouse gases is an important part of this century’s energy challenge, for sure.

Andy, disturbing that you seem to think that it is one versus another (growing populations, or bad housing, or coastal development VERSUS the risks of climate change). It is simply both, and we have to deal with both. No climatologist argues that we should ignore population or bad building design. Yet you argue we should ignore climate influence.

This is most obvious in your line: "I’m not denying it’s possible, just that it’s relevant." If it is possible, of COURSE it is relevant.

Moreover, it is not only "possible," it is undeniable that there could be a climate link in ever meteorological event now. Mann has it right.

I haven't set this It's important to pursue the science that might clarify a connection, and it's important to get busy finding ways to curb global growth in greenhouse gases. But neither of those activities are relevant to policy questions related to cutting vulnerability to terrible tornadoes in the American South, to my mind.

You may have missed this line:

Finding ways to curb emissions of greenhouse gases is an important part of this century’s energy challenge, for sure.

The USA adds about 30 million people each decade. That's a Canada, or a Venezuela, or a Morocco, or a California. If she continues this pattern over the next 9 decades, that will be an additional 270 million people by century's end. 313+270= 583, almost 600 million by 2100.
The heck with Nigeria, we need to talk about stabilizing population growth here, in the 3rd most populous nation on the planet.

Overpopulation is the root cause of most everything that afflicts our world right now but who took the concept of zero population growth off the table for discussion?

Way back in the 70's we were allowed to have an honest dialogue about the need for this goal. Like everything else it seems, the issue seems to be reduced to whether individuals can afford their children, not the impact they have on the sustainability of the current and future environment.

Housing pattern change is the root cause of more deaths in recent years. In the field of science the statements of Kevin Trenberth such as "Everyone's entitled to his or her view; It is irresponsible not to mention climate change" have no place. In the previous blog a map of trend of Fo to F5 were given. This map does not show any trend in F1 to F5 levels. However, Fo show an abrupt rise and continuing after 1989 or so. Scientists must look at thisissue why an abrupt shift in Fo and why not in F1 to F5? Blind attribution to climate change is not science. Here climate change include even the systematic pattern. When scientists identified zones of hazardous events, it is the responsibility of the administration to think and plan to minimise the impact of such hazardous even on life and property.

Dr. S. Jeevananda Reddy

Dear Experts, and also those Dot Earthlings who are inexpert in population science,

There are an abundance of researchers among us in the Dot Earth community and in other time-spaces, top-rank professionals who do lay claim to having adequate expertise in the science of human population numbers and non-human population numbers. After a decade of denial and elective mutism, I would like to respectfully ask for critiques/interpretations from you on the subject of human population dynamics, as human population dynamics has been presented in the scientific research of Hopfenberg and Pimentel.

There are two questions for which responses are requested from experts as well as those who are inexpert.

Question One:

Is the population dynamics of the human species different from, or essentially similar to, the population dynamics of non-human species? Please explain.

Question Two:

With regard to human population dynamics, is food the dependent variable or the independent variable in the relationship between absolute global numbers of humankind and the supply of food needed to maintain human existence? Please explain.

Thanks always,

Steve

Trying to pin global warming on last week's tornado outbreak is pseudoscientific hogwash. The tri-state tornado of 1925 remains America's most deadly on record, when the population was a third of what it is now. There's few meterological records of tornados before 1925, as there was little technology and fewer people around  to photograph let alone record them. The Xenia Ohio outbreak of 1974 was also horrific. What we have have in the USA  are lots of pseudoscientists jumping to conclusions to to fudge the data to deliver their desired outcome, free taxpayer money in the form of dubious climate change research grants. It's more than psuedoscience, it's a slap in the face to last week's victims who need more tornado shelters, and better tornado path prediction. Real scientists would better work on tornado prediction and warning systems.
